revision.text:
{{redirect|MOAB||Moab (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox Weapon |name= GBU-43/B Massive Ordnance Air Blast |image= [[Image:MOAB bomb.jpg|275px]] |origin= United States |type= Conventional bomb <!-- Type selection --> |is_ranged=yes |is_bladed= |is_explosive=yes |is_artillery= |is_vehicle= |is_UK= <!-- Service history --> |service= Since 2003 |used_by= [[United States Air Force]], [[Royal Air Force]] |wars= <!-- Production history --> |designer= [[Air Force Research Laboratory]] |design_date= 2002 |manufacturer= [http://mcalestr-www.army.mil/ McAlester Army Ammunition Plant] |production_date= 2003 |variants= <!-- General specifications --> |weight= {{convert|22600|lb|disp=flip|abbr=on}} |length= {{convert|30|ft|1.75|in|disp=flip|abbr=on}} |part_length= |width= |height= |crew= <!-- Ranged weapon specifications --> |cartridge= |caliber= |action= |rate= |velocity= |range= |max_range= |feed= |sights= <!-- Artillery specifications --> |breech= |recoil= |carriage= |elevation= |traverse= <!-- Bladed weapon specifications --> |blade_type= |hilt_type= |sheath_type= |head_type= |haft_type= <!-- Explosive specifications --> |diameter= {{convert|40.5|in|cm|abbr=on|disp=flip}} |filling= [[Composition H6|H-6]] |filling_weight= {{convert|18700|lb|abbr=on|disp=flip}} |detonation= |yield= 11 tons [[TNT equivalent|TNT]] <!-- Vehicle specifications --> |armour= |primary_armament= |secondary_armament= |engine= |engine_power= |pw_ratio= |suspension= |vehicle_range= |speed= }}
The '''GBU-43/B Massive Ordnance Air Blast''' ('''MOAB''' pronounced {{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|oh|.|ae|b}}, commonly known as the '''Mother of All Bombs''') is a large-yield conventional (non-nuclear) [[bomb]], developed for the United States military by Albert L. Weimorts, Jr. of the [[Air Force Research Laboratory]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/dec/27/local/me-passings27.3 |title=Albert L. Weimorts Jr. 67; Engineer Created 'Bunker Buster' Bombs|author=Times Wire Services |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=27 December 2005 |accessdate=8 July 2010}}</ref> At the time of development, it was touted as the most powerful non-[[nuclear weapon]] ever designed.<ref name="gs">{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/munitions/moab.htm |title=GBU-43/B "Mother Of All Bombs" / Massive Ordnance Air Blast Bomb |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=globalsecurity.org |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> The bomb was designed to be delivered by a [[C-130 Hercules]], primarily the [[MC-130|MC-130E Combat Talon I]] or [[MC-130|MC-130H Combat Talon II]] variants.
Since then, Russia has tested its "[[Father of All Bombs]]", which is claimed to be four times as powerful as the MOAB.<ref name=guard>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/russia/article/0,,2167175,00.html |title=Russia unveils the 'father of all bombs' |author=Luke Harding|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=12 September 2007 |accessdate=12 September 2007}}</ref>
==Operational history== MOAB was first tested with the explosive [[tritonal]] on 11 March 2003, on Range 70 located at [[Eglin Air Force Base]] in [[Florida]]. It was again tested on 21 November 2003.<ref name=gs/>
Aside from two test articles, the only known production is of 15 units at the [[McAlester Army Ammunition Plant]] in 2003 in support of the [[Iraq War]]. As of early 2007, none of those are known to have been used, although a single MOAB was moved to the [[Persian Gulf]] area in April 2003.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/meast/04/09/sprj.irq.moab.gulf/ MOAB bomb moved to Iraq war region]</ref>
==Evaluations== The basic operational concept bears some similarity to the [[BLU-82]] ''Daisy Cutter'', which was used to clear heavily wooded areas in the [[Vietnam War]] and in [[Iraq]] to clear mines and later as a psychological weapon against the Iraqi military. After the psychological impact of the BLU-82 on enemy soldiers was witnessed, and no BLU-82 weapons remained, the MOAB was developed partly to continue the ability to intimidate Iraqi soldiers. Pentagon officials had suggested their intention to use MOAB as an [[anti-personnel weapon]], as part of the "[[shock and awe]]" strategy integral to the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.nationalreview.com/owens/owens031203.asp |title= Enter Moab |accessdate =9 December 2011 |year= 2003|publisher= [[National Review Online]]}}</ref>
The MOAB is not a [[Penetration (weapons)|penetrator weapon]] and is primarily intended for soft to medium surface targets covering extended areas and targets in a contained environment such as a deep canyon or within a cave system. However, multiple strikes with lower yield ordnance may be more effective and can be delivered by fighter/bombers such as the [[F-16]] with greater stand-off capability than the [[C-130]] and [[C-17 Globemaster III|C-17]]. High altitude [[Carpet bomb|carpet-bombing]] with much smaller {{convert|500|to|2000|lb|disp=flip|adj = on}} bombs delivered via heavy bombers such as the [[B-52 Stratofortress|B-52]], [[B-2 Spirit|B-2]], or the [[Rockwell B-1 Lancer|B-1]] is also highly effective at covering large areas.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://usmilitary.about.com/od/weapons/l/aabombs4.htm |title= United States Military Weapons of War |accessdate =9 December 2007 |year= 2007 |publisher= about.com}}</ref>
<gallery class="center" widths=225px heights=200px> Image:MOABAFAM.JPG|GBU-43/B on display at the [[Air Force Armament Museum]], [[Eglin Air Force Base]], [[Florida]]. Note the [[grid fin]]s. Image:MOABprototype.jpg|Al Weimorts (right), the creator of the GBU-43/B Massive Ordnance Air Blast bomb, and Joseph Fellenz, lead model maker, look over the prototype before it was painted and tested. Image:MOABtest.jpg|Prototype MOAB an instant before impact on Eglin AFB's Range 70. </gallery>
